metadata.product: Gabrylly Ergonomic Mesh Office Chair, High Back Desk Chair

transcript.speaker: **Interviewer
transcript.text: ** Jessica (Corporate Representative)

transcript.speaker: **Interviewee
transcript.text: ** Janet (Customer)

transcript.speaker: **Jessica
transcript.text: ** Hi Janet, thank you so much for taking the time to speak with me today. My name is Jessica, and I’m calling from Gabrylly. We really appreciate you sharing your feedback about your ergonomic mesh office chair, and we wanted to follow up and understand your experience a bit more deeply.

transcript.speaker: **Janet
transcript.text: ** Oh, no problem, Jessica. Happy to chat. I mean, like I said in the review, I have some thoughts.

transcript.speaker: **Jessica
transcript.text: ** Absolutely, and that’s exactly what we want to hear. Your honest feedback is invaluable for us to improve. To start, could you tell me a little more about what initially led you to choose the Gabrylly chair? What were you looking for in a new office chair, especially coming from your previous one?

transcript.speaker: **Janet
transcript.text: ** Well, my old chair, bless its heart, was a hand-me-down from my uncle, probably from the 90s, super busted. The armrest was broken, the cushioning was completely gone. So, I was desperate. I run my own graphic design studio – it’s just me, really – and I spend, like, eight to ten hours a day, sometimes more, sitting. I knew I needed something supportive. I also wanted something that looked good, you know? My studio is also my spare bedroom, so aesthetics actually matter to me. I saw your chair online, and it just *looked* modern, sleek, the mesh seemed cool. And, of course, the "ergonomic" part was a big draw.

transcript.speaker: **Jessica
transcript.text: ** That makes perfect sense. So, both the look and the promise of ergonomic comfort were key factors. Did you consider any other brands or specific models before landing on ours?

transcript.speaker: **Janet
transcript.text: ** Yeah, I did a fair bit of browsing, mostly online, just looking at chairs in a similar price range, maybe a little higher. I can't remember all the names, honestly. There were a few that had really plush-looking seats, but then they usually looked a bit… clunky? Not as stylish. And some were just way out of my budget. Yours seemed like a good balance – looked professional, good reviews on the breathable mesh, and that ergonomic claim. I thought, "Okay, this is it, this is the upgrade."

transcript.speaker: **Jessica
transcript.text: ** I understand. And when you first received the chair, what were your initial impressions? You mentioned assembly was straightforward, mostly.

transcript.speaker: **Janet
transcript.text: ** Yeah, for the most part. It wasn't, like, rocket science. I think there were a couple of screws, though, that just didn't want to go in smoothly. They felt a bit… cross-thread-y, you know? I had to be really careful not to strip them. But eventually, I got it all together. And once it was built, yeah, it looked great. Definitely elevated the space. The mesh felt good to the touch, too. I was pretty optimistic at that point.

transcript.speaker: **Jessica
transcript.text: ** Good to hear that the aesthetics lived up to your expectations, and the mesh was a positive. You also mentioned in your review that the mesh offers excellent breathability, which is essential for you. Could you expand on how that impacts your daily work, especially during those long creative sessions?

transcript.speaker: **Janet
transcript.text: ** Oh, absolutely. That’s definitely a huge plus. My old chair was, like, pleather, and it would just get sticky and hot, especially if I was really focused, head down on a project for hours. By the end of the day, my back would feel gross. With the mesh, that’s just not an issue. It really does keep you cooler, and that makes a difference when you’re trying to concentrate and deadlines are looming. No more peel-yourself-off-the-chair feeling. So, that part, honestly, is great.

transcript.speaker: **Jessica
transcript.text: ** That’s valuable feedback, thank you. Now, let's shift to some of the challenges you've experienced. You highlighted that the major positives largely ended there, particularly with long-term comfort and ergonomic effectiveness. Could you describe how that feeling develops over your workday?

transcript.speaker: **Janet
transcript.text: ** Sure. So, for the first hour or two, honestly, it’s fine. It feels okay. But after about three, maybe four hours, that’s when things really start to go downhill. I start feeling a lot of pressure on my sit bones, like the seat just gets really, really firm. It’s not soft, it doesn’t have that… give, you know? It feels like I’m sitting on a hard surface, just covered with mesh. I find myself constantly shifting around, trying to relieve the pressure, but it doesn't really work. And that’s super distracting when I’m trying to focus on intricate design work.

transcript.speaker: **Jessica
transcript.text: ** That sounds quite uncomfortable and counterproductive for long hours. And when you say it lacks "subtle give or cushioning," what kind of sensation or material do you think would address that pressure point?

transcript.speaker: **Janet
transcript.text: ** Hmm, that’s a good question. I guess something that just… conforms a bit more? Or has a bit of a softer layer underneath the mesh. Like, imagine a memory foam mattress, but for your butt, you know? Not super squishy, but enough to distribute the weight better. This just feels like it’s stretching over a hard frame, and after a while, it just doesn’t have enough give. I don't know the exact material, but something that wouldn't feel so rigid after a few hours.

transcript.speaker: **Jessica
transcript.text: ** That’s a very clear description, thank you. Let's talk about the lumbar support. You mentioned it offers *some* support, but it's not as customizable or precise as you'd like, pushing into a broad area rather than specific pain points. Could you elaborate on what an ideal lumbar support system would look like for you, given your long hours and the nature of your work?

transcript.speaker: **Janet
transcript.text: ** Okay, so, with this chair, the lumbar knob just pushes a piece of plastic into your lower back. It's a very general push. My back pain isn't always in one spot. Sometimes it's a bit higher, sometimes it's lower, or to one side. I’ve seen other chairs – though not necessarily in my price range at the time – that have, like, independent adjustable pads, or maybe the whole backrest can tilt more specifically. I wish I could really target *where* the support is, not just how *much* pressure. And the range of adjustment feels limited too; it doesn’t really extend high enough for my back, so it just pushes into a broad area instead of cradling the natural curve.

transcript.speaker: **Jessica
transcript.text: ** So, more nuanced, targeted adjustability, rather than a broad, uniform push. That's very helpful. You also mentioned the armrests developing a wobble after a few weeks. How does that instability affect your work, especially when you're doing precise mouse work as a graphic designer?

transcript.speaker: **Janet
transcript.text: ** Oh, it’s annoying. Really annoying. They’re height-adjustable, which is good, but even locked into place, they just feel… loose now. If I’m leaning a little on my elbow for stability while I’m doing really fine detail work with my mouse or stylus, it just wobbles. It’s distracting. It makes them feel cheap, honestly, and not very reliable. I haven't broken them yet, but it feels like they could go at any time, and that makes me hesitant to really use them for support when I need it.

transcript.speaker: **Jessica
transcript.text: ** I can certainly see how that would be frustrating and impact your focus. And the headrest, you found it positioned a bit too low for your 5'9" height, feeling more like a neck rest. What's your ideal scenario for a headrest?

transcript.speaker: **Janet
transcript.text: ** Yeah, exactly, it’s a neck rest. When I try to lean back and relax, it just hits me in the middle of my neck, not really supporting my head. To get my head to actually rest on it, I have to kind of slouch down, which defeats the whole purpose of an *ergonomic* chair, right? Ideally, I’d want it to adjust higher, significantly higher, so that the curve supports the back of my head and neck together, allowing me to fully recline without straining. Or maybe even have a bit more curve to it, a bit more cushioning there too.

transcript.speaker: **Jessica
transcript.text: ** It sounds like you're looking for a more comprehensive and adjustable head/neck support that genuinely cradles your head when reclined. Finally, on the functional aspects, you mentioned the recline function is fine, but the tilt lock isn’t as robust as you’d hoped. Could you explain what you mean by "not robust"?

transcript.speaker: **Janet
transcript.text: ** It just doesn’t feel super secure. Like, when I lock it into a reclined position, it feels like it might slip or give a little if I put too much pressure on it. I haven't had it completely fail on me, but there's a slight give, a tiny bit of play, even when it's supposed to be locked solid. It just doesn't inspire a lot of confidence, so I find myself not really trusting it for prolonged leaning back. I mostly use it to rock a little, then lock it upright.

transcript.speaker: **Jessica
transcript.text: ** Okay, so it’s more about the perceived stability and a slight feeling of give. Considering all these points – the seat pressure, lumbar support, armrest wobble, headrest height, and tilt lock – how has this chair impacted your day-to-day work and even your physical well-being?

transcript.speaker: **Janet
transcript.text: ** Oh, it definitely impacts my work. I mean, my old chair was awful, so this is *marginally* better, but it's not the solution I hoped for. I still get aches and pains, especially in my lower back and my sit bones, after a few hours. It breaks my concentration when I’m constantly fidgeting or getting up to stretch. I just feel more fatigued at the end of the day than I should, considering I invested in an "ergonomic" chair. Sometimes I even go work on my couch just to change positions, which isn't ideal for graphic design. It's just... a constant reminder that it's not quite right.

transcript.speaker: **Jessica
transcript.text: ** I appreciate your candor, Janet. It's clear this isn't delivering the long-term comfort you truly need for your demanding work schedule. Given your experience, if you were speaking directly to our product development team, what would be your top one or two suggestions for improving this chair?

transcript.speaker: **Janet
transcript.text: ** My absolute top priority would be the seat cushioning. That pressure on my sit bones is probably the worst part. It needs more give, more actual cushioning, not just mesh over a hard surface. And then, tied for first, probably the lumbar support. It needs to be more targeted and have a wider range of adjustment, both horizontally and vertically. Like, if you could make those two things significantly better, I think it would be a completely different chair. The armrests too, just make them more solid. They don't need fancy features, just stability.

transcript.speaker: **Jessica
transcript.text: ** Those are very concrete and actionable suggestions, thank you. Thinking about your next chair, what would be the absolute non-negotiable features that a chair would need to have for you to consider it a true investment, even if it meant a higher price point? What would make you switch to a competitor if they offered it?

transcript.speaker: **Janet
transcript.text: ** Oh, definitely. If I found a chair that truly supported my lower back, like, actually contoured and adjusted specifically, and had a seat that I could sit in for eight hours without feeling like my bones were bruising, I'd probably pay significantly more. I’m talking a real difference in comfort. The breathable mesh is a plus, so if a competitor had that *and* genuinely superior ergonomics, I’d switch in a heartbeat. I’m looking for a chair that I don't even have to think about, that just lets me do my work comfortably all day. That’s the dream, honestly.

transcript.speaker: **Jessica
transcript.text: ** That dream chair, one that allows you to focus solely on your creative work without discomfort, is what we strive for. We truly value this kind of detailed feedback, Janet, as it helps us understand the real-world impact of our designs. Just one last question: on a scale of 1 to 10, with 1 being "extremely dissatisfied" and 10 being "extremely satisfied," how would you rate your overall satisfaction with your Gabrylly Ergonomic Mesh Office Chair today?

transcript.speaker: **Janet
transcript.text: ** Hmm. That’s tough. I mean, it *looks* good, and the mesh breathability is a real win. But the core ergonomic promise for long hours just isn’t there. It’s better than my old broken chair, sure, but not what I expected for an "ergonomic" upgrade. I’d have to say… probably a 4. It’s not terrible, but it definitely didn’t hit the mark for my needs.

transcript.speaker: **Jessica
transcript.text: ** A 4. Thank you for that honest rating, Janet. We truly appreciate your time and willingness to share such detailed insights. This information is incredibly valuable to us as we work to refine and improve our products. Is there anything else you'd like to add before we conclude?

transcript.speaker: **Janet
transcript.text: ** No, I think that covers it. Just hoping you guys can make some changes, because it really does have potential to be a great chair if those comfort issues were sorted out.

transcript.speaker: **Jessica
transcript.text: ** We're committed to doing just that. Thank you again, Janet. Have a great rest of your day.

transcript.speaker: **Janet
transcript.text: ** You too, Jessica. Bye. ---
